title: Petersburg National Battlefield: Learn About the Park
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park           Learn About the Park       An American City Under Siege         Ruins of the Taylor House dependency. The Taylor House, located at tour stop 7 of the Eastern Front Unit, is thought to have been destroyed during the opening attacks on Petersburg in mid-June, 1864. NPS       Keep In Touch Stay informed about park happenings through photographs and social media (http://www.nps.gov/pete/learn/photosmultimedia/index.htm) or, check out our latest news (http://www.nps.gov/pete/learn/news/index.htm) !  Explore the Park If you're a teacher looking for activities for your class, check out our Education page (http://www.nps.gov/pete/learn/education/index.htm) , there, you will be able to download our Educator's Guide which offers an assortment of field trip programs. Kids and youth can find fun ways to learn about history by participating in our Junior Ranger program and Summer Day Camps (http://www.nps.gov/pete/learn/kidsyouth/index.htm)  Life in the Trenches 292 days living in trenches made life miserable for the thousands of soldiers involved in the siege. Disease, loneliness, dispair, and horror were just some of the words used to describe the soldiers' experience at Petersburg. Discover more by visiting our History and Culture pages (http://www.nps.gov/pete/learn/historyculture/index.htm) .  Caring for the Natural Landscape The Battlefield's creeks and forest provide a habitat for a variety of species such as deer, wild turkey, eagles, and the occasional bear. Many of the plant and animal species were depended on by soldiers for food and medicinal purposes. Learn more about the natural side of your park in our Nature section (http://www.nps.gov/pete/learn/nature/index.htm) .
